translated: Sutra of the Wise and Foolish, Scroll 6
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Dharmaraká¹£a of the Western Jin
Chapter 19: The Eight Equalities
The Buddha told Bodhisattva Joyful King:
What are the six things of the perfection of the eight equalities?
If one has faith in the eight equalities, is devoted and upholds them without falling into the eight wrong paths, this is called giving;
In the practice of the eight equalities, upholding the Dharma without being attached to worldly glory, this is called morality;
Already in equal practice, abiding in equal karma, and attaining mastery without being deceived by others, this is called patience;
In a single sitting, attaining arhatship, practicing to transcend the three realms without further birth and death, this is called vigor;
Because of the eight equalities, attaining the path of the stream-enterer, coming and going without returning, and becoming a non-attached true person, this is called meditation;
Transcending the many streams and discerning the various, embracing this meaning of unsurpassed true reality, this is called wisdom;
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of the Dharma of bearing the traces of the Way?
Following the traces of the Way, one gradually attains illumination, eliminating the five hindrances, desire, anger, ignorance, drowsiness, and agitation, this is called giving;
Extinguishing desires and no longer engaging in impure conduct, this is called upholding precepts;
Returning to the world and heavens seven times before exhausting the various defilements, this is called patience;
Begging from house to house to bless all, attaining peace in life after life, this is called vigor;
Upholding the body, speech, and mind with a single practice;
Abandoning all unprofitable actions, this is called meditation;
Being unattached and understanding the emptiness of the three realms, this is called wisdom;
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of the dust of the once-returner?
Although in the three realms, seeing desire gradually turning to extinction, this is called giving;
If one sees the difficulties of afflictions, desires, and love, and the mind never offends, this is called upholding precepts;
If one observes that faults and transgressions gradually become thinner and ultimately non-existent, this is called patience;
If one uses clarity and sharpness to observe that faults and transgressions are formed from one's actions, this is called vigor;
If one sees the burning away of all desires and love without remainder, this is called meditation;
If one understands the origin of birth and death in one's life, and removes attachment without further suffering,
this is called wisdom;
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of non-returning?
If one is able to distance oneself from attachments to the desire realm, practice the four kinds of kindness and four equalities without weariness, this is called giving;
If the mind is without the difficulties of remaining defilements, and completely exhausts its origin without returning to the world, this is called upholding precepts;
If one is born in the twenty-two heavens of good bestowal, practices above without abandoning the path's work, this is called patience;
Diligence in practice day and night, keeping the mind in the Dharma, if born in the twenty-third heaven of good giving nature, this is diligence;
If born in the twenty-fourth heaven without the knot of craving, being at ease above with a mind seeking no heavens, this is concentration;
If by closely following the path of the six supernormal powers and right practice, one attains the treasury of wisdom, this is wisdom;
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of non-attachment?
Extinguishing the Dharma of sudden loss and error, up to arhatship, this is giving;
No longer needing to uphold the Dharma of non-forgetfulness, it is naturally exhausted, this is upholding the precepts;
If by firm faith one attains liberation with a mind free from doubt, this is patience;
If by understanding wisdom one reaches the end of birth, old age, sickness, and death, this is diligence;
Dissolving all calamities and the difficulties of the three evil paths, personally verifying it, this is concentration;
Together they attain liberation, and the cycle of birth and death is forever ended without remainder. This is wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six things of the perfection of pratyekabuddhahood?
Observing few affairs, dwelling in the mountains in solitude, not greedy for body and life, not engaging in crowds, this is giving;
Giving rise to the right man's work, selecting the Dharma, the correct truth being the same, able to lead with the right time, this is upholding the precepts;
Dwelling alone, guarding one's will without being lax, this is patience;
Attaining liberation, crossing the three realms, no longer bound by fetters, this is vigor;
If one cultivates tranquility and reaches equanimity, the mind is unattached, this is meditation;
Attaining the single product, the basis of the correct truth, vast and in accord with the Dharma, without a second product, this is wisdom;
These are the six.
What are the six things of the perfection of bodhisattvas?
The practice of rescue is always with an impartial mind, without flattery, this is giving;
To attain the nature of harmony and always practice peace and comfort in order to heal the mind;
To teach and transform according to their dispositions, this is called upholding the precepts;
If one can add equanimity to sentient beings without harming them, this is called patience;
If one can practice the profound and essential Dharma of emptiness, the unsurpassed great way, and the truth, and attain omniscience, this is called vigor;
Not relying on the teachings of others, but practicing and returning to the small section, and attaining the equality of samÄdhi, this is called meditation;
Not being weary of saá¹ƒsÄra, but guiding all sentient beings with wisdom, this is called wisdom;
These are the six.
What are the six things of the perfection of wisdom?
If one uses wisdom to cultivate what should be done without falling into lack, this is called giving;
If one uses good principles to heal various practices, and purifies body, speech, and mind, this is called upholding the precepts;
If one's practice eliminates defilements, is pure and bright, and is without conceptualization, this is called patience;
To eliminate all delusions and take pleasure in the true and correct, and to proclaim what is appropriate and follow the teachings of the Buddha's Dharma, this is diligence.
To be unstinting and able to rescue all from misfortune with one's possessions, and to diligently cultivate the true and correct, this is concentration.
To be able to abandon unwholesome karma and all ignorance, and to attain the lofty and sagely six supernormal powers and reach omniscience, this is wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of the wisdom of non-arising?
To understand that the basis of desire and the arising of desire are all empty and without arising, this is giving.
To cause there to be no going or returning and to understand non-arising, this is upholding the precepts.
Not to have any connection with worldly dharmas but to purely cultivate the Dharma, this is patience.
To single-mindedly cultivate the gates of liberation, emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness without forgetting, this is diligence.
The reason one is able to see the wisdom of non-arising;
It is because one sees that everything is non-existent.
This is called concentration.
To eliminate all thoughts and defilements and not harbor delusions is called wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six matters of establishing the perfection of meditation?
Whether the true Dharma abides or perishes, to not abandon the Way and to attain clothing, food, sustenance, and fame is giving.
To have nothing to rely on in the Dharma teachings and to have a mind equal to space is upholding the precepts.
To be able to delight the four kinds of people and not rely on the four is patience.
If one diligently cultivates skillful means and seeks the fruit of the true and supreme Way, this is vigor.
When in the asura realm, always studying the scriptures and not abandoning the Three Jewels is meditation.
All worlds hear their Dharma and immediately accept and practice it without any deviant mind, this is wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six matters of attaining the perfection of the heavenly eye?
If with the heavenly eye one sees all forms but the mind is unattached and understands their emptiness, this is called giving.
If one can clearly see formlessness and practice skillful means without falling into the desire realm, this is called upholding precepts.
If one can understand formlessness and the mind is equanimous without aversion or attachment, this is called patience.
If one observes the difficulties of birth and death, coming and going, without being constrained or fearful, this is called diligence.
If one sees the absence of thought and all thoughts are equal, without internal or external obstacles or anything to rely on, this is called meditation.
If one sees tranquility and the mind is serene, like space that cannot be measured, this is called wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six matters of the perfection of heavenly ear?

If one can hear all the languages and sounds of sentient beings, the music and singing of the heavens, and the cries of the hells, hungry ghosts, and animals, and be kind towards them, this is called giving.
If one can cause others to hear subtle sounds, understand that all words are empty and without expression, this is called upholding precepts.
If all one's actions accord with the path and its practices, and one does not follow the sixty-two views of non-Buddhist teachings, this is called patience.
If one proclaims with the mouth and thinks in the mind, skillfully adapting to the appropriate timing and using wisdom to transform, this is called vigor.
If one hears of all emptiness and the absence of myriad things, and receives and upholds the scriptures and their teachings, this is called meditation.
If one comprehends all sounds and knows them to be ultimately extinguished, returning to the tranquil unsurpassed true reality, this is called wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six matters of the perfection of knowing the minds of others?
If the mind sees all places by oneself, and wishes to save the three realms of suffering, this is called giving.
If the mind universally sees good and bad principles, and this mind is impartial and does not dwell in conditioned arising, this is called upholding precepts.
Observing all causes and conditions, karmic retribution and karmic activity are originally without conditions or opposites, this is called patience.
If one sees past and future events, all of them are clearly understood and one sees their beginning and end, this is called vigor.
Equally viewing present events, all of them are like illusions, this is called meditation.
Universally seeing the beginning and end of all practices, there is no beginning or end, and nothing essential exists, this is called wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six things of recollecting the past in the perfection of recollection?
Seeing the past lives and experiences of recollection, and the right and wrong of past practices, this is called giving.
Accomplishing what should be done and using it to encourage and assist unsurpassed true enlightenment, this is called upholding precepts.
Not using frequent coming and going, all are extinguished and allowed to be born nowhere, this is called patience;
Using this name as nonexistent, seeing all origins, this is called meditation;
Proclaiming the scriptures in various categories, teaching and transforming the three realms, benefiting those in danger and misfortune, this is called wisdom;
These are the six.
What is meant by the six things of the perfection of spiritual powers and flying?
Attaining spiritual powers, flying to the ten directions wherever one wishes, this is called giving;
The skillful means practiced always accord with the meaning of the Dharma, understanding the emptiness of the five skandhas and not being destroyed, this is called morality;
Giving rise to great compassion and pity for sentient beings, wishing to deliver them, this is called patience;
The practice is complete, like the full moon shining among the stars without any loss, this is called vigor;
If one can restrain the five skandhas, the six sense faculties, and the twelve links of dependent origination, suppressing one's will, this is called meditation;
If one is not diligent, one should be urged to practice diligently and enter the ultimate sagehood, this is wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six things of the perfection of ending outflows?
Seeing oneself and others, not considering others as oneself, and having no outflows, this is giving;
Observing all outflows, knowing they arise from habits, and causing them not to arise, this is upholding precepts;
Seeing that the roots of all outflows are originally non-existent and are all extinguished, this is patience;
Personally attaining the observation of the extinction of all outflows, with nothing to extinguish, not seeing the destination of birth and death, this is diligence;
Causing the fundamental outflows to naturally be eternally without remainder, this is concentration;
Using the power of diligence to uproot all outflows, seeing they have no location and no destination, this is wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six things of the perfection of deportment?
Using dignified conduct to cause countless people to all use propriety and be harmonious and joyful is called giving.
Universally delighting all beings, none are not delighted to receive the Dharma teachings, this is called upholding the precepts.
Concentrating on contemplation without negligence, only preserving the great way, this is called patience.
Coming and going peacefully without haste, this is called vigor.
Dignified conduct without deficiency, complete with propriety, this is called meditation.
Seeing profound and distant karma, brightly shining without basis, with perfect virtue, this is called wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six matters of the perfection of compassion?
If there are evil people with heretical poison in their hearts, nourishing them with clothing and food to rescue and aid them, this is called giving.
Seeing violent and harmful people who encounter difficulties and dangers, rescuing and protecting them and then showing them the path of the sutras, this is called upholding the precepts.
If one can endure the self-conceit and ambition of non-Buddhists, this is called patience.
If one expounds the meaning of the Dharma to the assembly like a lotus in a pond, this is called vigor.
If one expounds the meaning of the Dharma with virtuous deeds to subdue oneself, this is called meditation.
If one goes to offer sacrifices and preaches the Dharma according to the occasion, speaking truthfully to transform the naked ones, this is called wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of practicing emptiness?
If one gives without being tired or lazy, transforming others to enter the path without worldly affairs, this is called giving.

If one acts freely and independently without following others' teachings, this is called upholding the precepts.ğŸ”½If one practices single-mindedly without turning back or falling into minor virtues, this is called patience.
If one practices to the end without attaining partial realization and completes the merit of the Buddha, this is called vigor.
To always be without reliance in what should be practiced and to cultivate with purity is called concentration.
To establish practices according to one's preferences and to guide and benefit all is called wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of abandonment?
To abandon the practice of life and not to crave the body, to act freely without obstruction, is called giving.
To abandon the present body, speech, and mind, and to have no attachment to the five destinies and birth and death, is called morality.
To peacefully practice the Dharma with the realm of bonds, and not to transgress the four immeasurable minds and the six pÄramitÄs, is called patience.
To abandon lust, anger, and delusion, and to abandon all other sufferings and views, such as the sixty-two kinds of views, is called vigor.
To enable sentient beings to cultivate with purity, and not to be arrogant in one's practice, is called concentration.
If one can free sentient beings from the sorrow of distress, and with a mind dwelling in the ultimate Dharma one accords with the teachings of the Vinaya, this is wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of attaining nirvana?
If one understands emptiness without delusion, and attains nirvana without giving rise to anything, this is giving;
If one establishes the mind in the great path, dwelling in the absence of a fixed location, this is morality;
If one abandons the comfort of the body and does not rely on body and life, yet transforms sentient beings, this is patience;
If one uses the power of spiritual penetrations to shake the trichiliocosm without frightening any devas or humans, this is vigor;
If one's mind is in meditation, with concentration and right acceptance, yet without attachment or negligence, this is meditation;
If after nirvana one scatters one's bodily remains, spreading them throughout the ten directions so that all receive grace, this is wisdom;
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of transformation?
The distribution of the relics is obtained everywhere, spreading throughout the world, this is called giving.
The relics manifest auspicious signs, with majestic radiance, none who see them are not delighted, this is called upholding the precepts.
Sentient beings, seeing the transformation, their minds filled with joy, thereby give rise to the aspiration for enlightenment, this is called patience.
The gods, seeing the majestic virtue, lofty and majestic, encourage and rejoice on behalf of it, this is called diligence.
If one sees the relics of the sage's feet emitting light, and the hairs on one's body stand on end, tears well up, this is called single-minded concentration.
If one sees the relics and makes a sincere vow, manifesting light and majestic virtue, with five colors shining brightly, this is called wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of spreading the Dharma teachings?
If one obtains the self-surrender and offerings of the multitude, providing for the lacking of the multitude, this is called giving.
Always guarding one's own mind, not allowing anything to arise, that which does not arise then does not cease, this is called upholding the precepts.
If one sees the three realms as nonexistent, the Buddha's teachings, people, and all things are naturally so. This is called patience.
If one can cause the scriptures, the way of the Dharma, and the teachings to flow in the heavens and pervade the world, this is called vigor.
If the demonic officials see this and shrink back, unable to bear the majestic countenance, this is called meditation.
If the Dharma teachings are clearly revealed and spread, loved and respected in the ten directions, each with joy, gradually attaining the Dharma of nirvana, this is called wisdom.
These are the six.
What are the six pÄramitÄs of distributing relics?
If one seeks relics and makes offerings day and night, this is called giving.
If countless people all rejoice and take refuge in making offerings, this is called upholding precepts.
If one manifests light and majestic spiritual power, and those who come from far and near transform each other's minds, this is called patience.
If the gods and people all rejoice together, knowing that the Supreme One gives rise to the intention of the Way due to this, this is diligence;
If one sees the relics and has no other joy, contemplating the Buddha's Way that is beyond comparison, this is concentration;
Praising the relics, attaining wonderful eloquence, and being unobstructed leads to wisdom;
This is the sixth.
At that time, the World-Honored One further instructed Joyful King Bodhisattva:

These two thousand one hundred perfections, moreover, there are ninety perfections that eliminate the world's nine vexations and transform the ninety-six kinds of non-Buddhist teachings to enter the true reality.

The Buddha told Joyful King Bodhisattva:ğŸ”½These two thousand one hundred perfections expound the Dharma and teach those of the lustful type;ğŸ”½Two thousand one hundred perfections expound the Dharma and transform those of the hateful type;
Two thousand one hundred perfections expound the Dharma and awaken those of the deluded type;
Two thousand one hundred perfections are explained and taught to transform equal distribution seeds.
This is the combination of eight thousand four hundred perfections, multiplied by ten, totaling eighty-four thousand perfections.

The Buddha is the king of physicians, the Dharma is the medicine for sentient beings in the three realms, which cures the three poisons, the five hindrances, and the equal distribution of retributions, and transforms those who do not return to the right path. Seeing this, they are guided to liberation. If one does not practice and follow these eighty-four thousand perfections, one may wish to eliminate the eighty-four thousand afflictions of the myriad people and attain the eighty-four thousand samÄdhi gates, but one will never succeed. Therefore, by cultivating and establishing the eighty-four thousand emptiness practices and principles, one transforms the myriad people, eliminates the eighty-four thousand afflictions, and attains the eighty-four thousand samÄdhi gates. This is called the Buddha's path, deeply penetrating to the ultimate and attaining omniscience.
The Buddha said to Joyful King:

I attained supreme perfect enlightenment by sitting under the bodhi tree and subduing the demon hordes. Based on this, I understood the Dharma and established equality. Sitting cross-legged on the ground, I then attained majestic and wondrous spiritual powers.
The Brahma King respectfully bowed down and took refuge, seeking forgiveness:
In the past, I made vows for all sentient beings. Now they have all gathered and wish to hear the sutra.
The Brahma King shed tears and earnestly encouraged:

Only save those who have not yet crossed the river of suffering and are confused. The Buddha has attained such a subtle and great sage, and has reached supreme perfect enlightenment and peacefully sits in silence. He silently thinks this in his mind: 'In the five turbidities and evil world, there are ninety-six paths and sixty-two views. The confused and violent ones are mostly ungrateful and do not accept the teachings of the Way. It is better to remain silent and enter parinirvÄá¹‡a.'

The Buddha sat under the tree, his radiance majestic, illuminating the ten directions. The gods of the Pure Abode Heaven saw from afar his majestic light, his countenance and merits all shining brightly, his virtue and auspicious karma all to be spread far and wide.

The assembly of gods all rejoiced, establishing great light, tranquil and true, holy and boundless, its bright radiance shining everywhere with majestic virtue, unsurpassed in purity, most revered in the three times, pervading all the Buddha-realms in the ten directions, its mind penetrating and moving the trichiliocosm, its path-wisdom vast and far-reaching, difficult to see or hear, transcending and boundless, its fame spreading far and wide.
Beholding this majestic and wondrous light, immeasurable in its radiance, its countenance and abundant virtue, its wisdom like empty space, unique and incomparable.
At that time, the Brahma King further addressed the Buddha, saying:
With trepidation and a focused mind, I respectfully take refuge.
He spoke this verse:
The Way-place emits great light, subduing demons and dispelling afflictions,
Shaking the lands of the trichiliocosm, extinguishing the sufferings of the evil destinies,
Sitting upright and at ease, unmoving like Mount Sumeru,
Radiating light illuminating the buddha-lands, none under the trees are not illuminated.
Sitting peacefully with tranquil faculties, like a fearless lion,
Seeing oneself about to attain quiescence, the supreme seat radiating light,
Displaying majesty under the king of trees, widely spreading the peaceful great way,
Eliminating worldly useless dharmas, extinguishing the calamities of the three evil paths.
Beholding the light, one never tires of it, the mind contemplates with sincere compassion,
Thoroughly contemplating and speaking the noble teachings, equally expounding the level and vast Dharma,
Selecting the way and the karmas of the three times, illuminating the dharmas of the three categories,
In a timely manner proclaiming the practice of the mind, manifesting the way like the full moon.
The thirty-two marks of physical excellence, the great sage father in the world,
Not abandoning the world's lack of joy, the divine incomparable Brahma comes.
Observing the world in the three fires, awakening to the mundane with the water of Dharma,
Always protecting and extinguishing burning, this is the time to rain the sweet dew.
Observing diligence without interruption, the deluded attain the right path,
The enlightened eye teaches without duality, only having compassion and instructing at the right time.
Virtue is like the ocean and great mountains, for the sake of the multitude, releasing the boat of awakening,
Thus crossing over the drowning currents, transforming the dangerous and deviant studies outside.
People are bound by greed and cling to the body, with wrong views harming their beloved servants,
Unable to escape the long prison, leading the multitude to be transformed and liberated.
Born in the deviant, growing in sleep, following the dust, not delighting in the Way,
Attaining concentration, precepts, and strong vows, why not beat the Dharma drum?
People lack and fall into prison, begging in the five realms of the world,
Always not attaining the inexhaustible, why not proclaim the sacrifice?
Countless multitudes harbor faith, in tranquility, abandoning the sweet dew,
Holding enlightenment can bring down the nourishing dew.
Knowing the wounds and illnesses of the three times, the ignorant mind's afflictions,
Having attained the pure medicine, why not save and heal?
Eliminating the obscurity of sentient beings, accomplishing the great virtue of the horse's hidden penis,
The light of wisdom illuminates the great trichiliocosm, why not illuminate the Buddha's country?
Only have compassion for the heavens and the people of the world, falling into the four swift torrents,
Why not save this calamity, protect those who fall into the great wilderness?
The Buddha sees the various thoughts, the heavens and humans standing with palms joined,
Without flattery, abandoning what is not peaceful, why not manifest the precious Dharma?
The Buddha's eye observes the three realms, the Brahma Heaven encourages the Honored One of humans,
Only have compassion for the multitude of wrong views, turn the Dharma wheel and eliminate the heat.
The Honored One sits on the lion seat, the heavens and humans gather here,
Standing here seeking nourishment, only turn the Dharma wheel.
Chapter 20: The Names of the Thousand Buddhas. Joyful King Bodhisattva again addressed the Buddha, saying:
Yes, World-Honored One!
Are there great beings in this assembly who have attained this concentration?
Have they entered these 8,400 perfections?
And the 84,000 perfections of the Dharma, have they entered the 84,000 samÄdhi gates?
The Buddha told Joyful King Bodhisattva:
In this assembly there are bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who have attained this concentration and the perfections, and have also entered these 84,000 samÄdhi gates.
Not only these bodhisattvas, but also those who will study in the future, the 1,000 tathÄgatas who will attain perfect enlightenment in this Bhadrakalpa,
with the exception of the four tathÄgatas who have already attained supreme perfect enlightenment in the past, they too have attained this samÄdhi.
Joyful King Bodhisattva again addressed the Buddha, saying:
Excellent!
World-Honored One!

Please have compassion and proclaim the names and titles of these bodhisattvas, who have great compassion and bring great peace and comfort, who have pity for the devas and people of the ten directions, who protect the true canon and ensure that the Dharma will endure for a long time, who bestow upon future bodhisattvas in training, who reveal the light and practice the unsurpassed true path and thereby achieve accomplishment.
The Buddha said to Bodhisattva Priyankara:ğŸ”½Listen carefully!
Listen carefully!
Contemplate it well!
I will explain the names and titles of the thousand buddhas for you.
Bodhisattva Priyankara and the great assembly accepted the teaching and listened.
At that time, the World-Honored One then praised and proclaimed the names of the buddhas:ğŸ”½Good to Contemplate,ğŸ”½Buddhas' Sounds,
Only Mindfulness of Peace,ğŸ”½Renown for Purity,ğŸ”½Greatly Renowned,
Jewel Topknot,ğŸ”½Firm Lion,ğŸ”½Walking Alone,
Abandoning Thoughts,

In that place, countless devas, Meru-prabha,
MahÄ-garbha, Uttama, PadmanÄbha,
Majestic and victorious, great realm, with stopping and protection,
Leading the three realms, with merit and virtue, proclaiming fame,
Sunlight, Lion's Excellence, Timely King,
Lion's Treasury, Showing Existence, Far-Reaching Light,
Stopping Lion, With Something to Give, Invincible,
Supreme Banner, Joyful Renown, Firmly Diligent,
Without Loss or Diminution, With Fame, Without Fear,
Without Attachment, Great Lamp, Worldly Light,

Unequaled.
The Buddha said to Joyful King Bodhisattva:
You should praise and chant the names of these bodhisattvas who will become Buddhas during the Worthy Eon:
Krakucchanda, Kanakamuni, KÄÅ›yapa,
ÅšÄkyamuni, Maitreya Buddha, Lion's Flame,
Gentle and Virtuous Buddha, and Wonderful Flower, Good Constellation,
And the Guide, Great Abundance, Powerful Buddha,
Constellation King, that YaÅ›as, Tranquil Hero,

Weishen Shou, Nansheng Shi, Debing Buddha,ğŸ”½Jingxian Ju, Fan Yin Xiang, Shunci Jian,

Mountain-peak Hero, known as DharmakÄ«rti, Understanding the truth,
Tamed nature, Buddha RatnÄkara, Remembering the supreme faculties,
Desiring to liberate, Abiding in enlightenment, Discriminating groups,
Surpassing the honored ones, Buddha Åširasketu, Raining sounds,
Good contemplation, having good intentions, Known as VimalaprabhÄ,
Greatly renowned, pure jewels, Firm lion,
Abiding in the tall tree, abandoning contemplation, Wisdom-peak,
Well-established, having determination, immeasurable intention,

In this Worthy Eon, there will be a thousand Buddhas appearing in the world to liberate all beings in the ten directions.
These thousand Buddhas each have names and appearances like this.

If there are people who hear and uphold them, recite them, study them, keep them in mind, understand them, practice without negligence, make offerings together, abandon the evil destinies and the suffering of hardship, and attain long-lasting peace and security abiding in the precepts, then all that they believe and rejoice in will accord with the sutra path, and they will encounter the pure and complete fruits. This profound and wonderful forbearance is the fundamental forbearance of the Dharma, protecting all worlds for many billions of eons.
Those who commit evil deeds and do not know the fruits and retributions of good and evil, upon hearing the names of the Buddhas, will eliminate all their offenses and have no more suffering.
If one upholds the names and titles of these Buddhas, one will attain spiritual powers and single-minded concentration.
